info.description:
⚠️⚠️⚠️ **This code is in an alpha testing phase, any of it is liable to change at any time.** ⚠️⚠️⚠️

PISA is an accountable watching service. PISA can be hired to watch for on-chain events by requesting an appointment. At its core PISA is a watch and respond service, you can configure PISA to watch for EVM events and provide it with data to respond with if the event occurs.

The PISA contract is deployed on Ropsten at [0xA02C7260c0020343040A504Ef24252c120be60b9](https://ropsten.etherscan.io/address/0xA02C7260c0020343040A504Ef24252c120be60b9), you will need to include this address when encoding the appointment for signature.
info.title: PISA Watchtower

tags.name: Appointment
tags.description:
An appointment specifies all the information that PISA requires to watch for an event, and respond with data. The appointment is loosely made up of four sections: 
1. Metadata: 
  * Customer address - address of the customer 
  * Appointment id - unique id chosen by the customer 
  * Nonce - counter that can be incremented to replace an appointment 
  * Start block - the block when the appointment starts, only events observed between start and end block will be responded to 
  * End block - the block when the appointment ends 
  * Refund - the amount to be refunded to the customer if the PISA fails to respond 
  * Payment hash - proof that the customer has paid PISA 
2. Event data 
  * Event address - The address that emits the tiggering event 
  * Event ABI - A human readable ABI that specifies the structure of the event 
  * Event args - The ABI encoded arguments used to filter the event 
3. Response data 
  * Contract address - The address that pisa will respond to 
  * Data - the data to be submitted by PISA on response 
  * Gas limit - the gas to be supplied to the response 
  * Challenge period - the amount of time after the event that PISA has to respond 
  * Mode - used to specify pre and post conditions 
  * Pre condition - not currently supported, set to `0x` 
  * Post condition - not currently supported, set to `0x` 
4. Signature data 
  * Customer sig - a signature by the private key corresponding to the customer address over the supplied appointment data.

post.summary: Request a new appointment from PISA

customerAddress.description: The address of the customer hiring PISA.

id.description: A unique id, chosen by the customer. Bytes32.

nonce.description: A counter used to replace appointments of the same id, but lower counter. A new appointment can be requested for an existing id as long as the nonce is incremented. If this is the case PISA will forget the old appointment and only watch for the new one.

startBlock.description: The block at which this appointment starts. Only events that occur after (inclusive) start block and before (inclusive) end block will be responded to.

endBlock.description: The last block in which the appointment is still valid.

refund.description: The amount to be refunded in case of failure (wei). Must be set to `0` for free API values, non zero values are not currently supported.

paymentHash.description: Proof that payment has been made to the PISA service. Whilst in its testing phase PISA operates for free :) Use the hash 0xfc1624bdc50da30f2ea37b7debabeac1f6166db013c5880dcf63907b04199138 to gain access to the service.

eventAddress.description: The address of the external contract from which the event will be emitted.

topics.description: TODO:340: outdated. PISA can be triggered by an event with specific arguments. This parameters allows to specify the topics of the log entry that should be matched. This parameter is an array where each element is the exact value of the topic of the log entry, or null if that topic is to be ignored. Note that for contracts generated in Solidity, the first topic is always the hash of the event signature.

contractAddress.description: The address of the external contract to which the data will be submitted.

gasLimit.description: The amount of gas that will be supplied when calling the external contract. Maximum is 2 million.

challengePeriod.description: The number of blocks that PISA has to respond if an event is noticed.

mode.description: Mode specifies which pre and post condition handlers will be called. Currently pre and post conditions are not supported, and mode can either be `0` or `1`. Set `0` for instant relay - PISA ignores all event information and immediately submits a response. Set `1` for PISA to watch for the specified event and only respond after it has been observed.
